title: just third children wales live poverty new report says
story: The report, which analysed the Family Resource Survey, blames a decade of austerity cuts and welfare reforms instigated by the UK Government.ldquoIt [the report] also shows that many of the most important levers to lt children and families out of poverty are not in our hands, said Julie James, who is responsible for co-ordinating Welsh Government action to tackle child poverty.ldquoAs a UN report recently highlighted, a decade of UK Government-driven austerity, and tax and welfare reforms, have landed most damagingly on those who are least able to manage.Ms James, who is also Minister for Housing and Local Government, added: ldquoIn addition, we are already feeling the repercussions of our decision to leave the European Union and expect to see levels of poverty in Wales increase as a result.The report said that the Welsh Governmentrsquos Child Poverty Strategy ndash which includes actions to create a strong economy, tackle worklessness, improve skills, tackle inequalities and increase household income ndash are mitigating the impact of poverty.Policies such as free prescriptions, free school meals, the education maintenance allowanceand a generous childcare offer, means some Welsh families are more than pound, a year better off, the report concluded.It said that Walesrsquo employment rate is above its historical average, with more than , more people in work since .The number of workless households in Wales has fallen more than  per cent, from , to ,, since devolution and the number of children living in workless households has fallen from , in to , in  .Ms James added: ldquoWe have always made tackling child poverty a priority and we have made signicant resources available to help those children and families most in need.ldquoBut despite the progress we have made, this report shows just how much more there is to do.ldquoFor many people work alone is not enough to lt families out of poverty. This is largely due to a combination of the impact of UK Government-driven austerity cuts and tax and welfare reforms combined with the rise in insecure, low paid work in recent years.ldquoWe want to see child poverty reducing ndash not increasing. We will continue to do everything we can to tackle poverty and its toxic effects. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA NEW simplied way of working to protect adults and children at risk of neglect or abuse is now in effect in two parts of Wales.Both the Cardf and the Vale and Gwent regional safeguarding boards have formally adopted the new Wales Safeguarding Procedures.Thousands of practitioners working with adults and children in these areas - such as teachers, nurses, social workers and volunteers ndash are now working to the same guidelines.Vale council director of social services and co-chair of the Cardf and the Vale Regional Safeguarding Board, Lance Carver said: ldquoThe adoption of the Wales Safeguarding Procedures by the first two regional safeguarding boards represents a signicant milestone in improving how we all work together to better protect those at risk or harm or neglect.ldquoAnyone can view the procedures online or download the app.ldquoThis is important as it means that everybody working with adults or children, no matter what they do, will always be able to find out quickly and easily what to dothey suspect an inidual is at risk.ldquoWe believe this will have a signicant impact on how and when potential incidents of harm or neglect are reported.Wales became the first part of the UK to introduce a single set of digital safeguarding guidelines when the Wales Safeguarding Procedures were launched in November.The procedures set out for anyone working with children or adults what to dothey suspect an inidual is experiencing, or at risk of, abuse, neglect or other kinds of harm.Uniquely there are no printed copies of the procedures.Instead they are available to everyone online, either via the dedicated Wales Safeguarding Procedures website or a mobile app.The Wales Safeguarding Procedures app is available for download via the Apple App Store and Google Play Store.The procedures can also be viewed in English at title: penarth weather forecast christmas
story: The Met Office has contradicted claims the UK is set to face the "coldest winter in  years".According to long range weather forecaster Exacta Weather, there could be blizzards on Christmas Day followed by a freezing cold January.Reports in The Express said the UK could see "some type of -year cold or snow records being breached this winter".But weather experts at the Met Office have said their long-range predictions are completely dferent.The weather forecaster said temperatures are likely to be above average for the time of year.According to the Met Office, the weather for Penarth during Christmas week is as Follows: "A more changeable spell is expected towards the end of December, with the greatest potential for heavy rain in the south and east at first, with any snow becoming confined to northern hills. A more typical northwest southeast split looks likely to develop into the New Year, bringing rain to the northwest interspersed with showers, and drier periods further south. This could be accompanied by a general upturn in temperatures, as well as the risk of strong winds at times."Currently a bet on snow falling on Christmas Day are about - in the south of England but lower in the north and in Scotland.The website "Will I Get A White Christmas " lists the chances as  per cent of a white Christmas for Edinburgh but for London, the chance is lower at  per cent.A Met Office spokesman said: "At the the moment, the longest range we are looking at is January, but this is not a forecast, its a probability."Were probably looking at milder than average conditions - so, not the coldest for  years, or a collapsed polar vortex."According to the long range weather forecast there could be some wintry showers at times between December  and December .However, a wet and rainy Christmas is looking far more likely than snowfall.It said: "Widespread frosts and ice are also likely. There looks to be a change around mid-month to milder conditions, although the timing is very uncertain."This change looks likely to bring milder and wetter conditions across most parts of the UK, allowing temperatures to recover to around average, or perhaps slightly above."The wettest conditions are likely to be in the north and west, with an increased likelihood of drier spells in the south and southeast."Colder interludes are still possible."There have only been four occasion in the UK in the last  years where more than  per cent of stations in the UK reported snow on the ground at am.After -cm of snow fell in the Highlands and mph winds occurred on the Welsh Coast a few weeks ago, bookmakers started offering odds on snowfall in a number of cities across the UK.However, betting odds have now changed, suggesting snow is less likely to fall in the UK this Christmas.A spokesman for William Hill said: "At this stage of the year, the odds always suggest that a White Christmas is a long shot."Its - against snow in Aberdeen on Christmas Day, - against snow in Glasgow, - against snow in Edinburgh, and - snow in Newcastle.London is -.According to long range weather forecaster Exacta Weather, there could be blizzards on Christmas Day followed by a freezing cold January. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ahead time   meet  year old vegan activist lives penarth
story: June Holder" Ahead of her time - Meet the -year-old vegan activist who lives in PenarthJune Holder with her umbrella full of vegan messages" Ahead of her time - Meet the -year-old vegan activist who lives in PenarthJune Holder" Ahead of her time - Meet the -year-old vegan activist who lives in PenarthJune Holder has dedicated  years to activism" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentPatricia lsquoJunersquo Holder became a vegan  years ago after she read a leaflet which showed the cruelty animals suffered in the meat industry. This year, she will celebrate her ninety second birthday and she discusses a letime of activism across Europe.Veganuary is an annual event which encourages people to go vegan for a month. In last yearrsquos campaign, a quarter of a million people pledged to try a vegan diet.More NewsVale school pals brave the shave for animal charityPenarth father of four is recognised in New Year Honour list for services to cricketHouse prices increased in the Vale of Glamorgan, latest figures showOnce a fringe movement, veganism is quickly gaining a vast appeal, especially amongst the young, as the environmental benefits of a plant-based diet become clearer.According to a study by the Vegan Society, , people in the UK were vegan in  ndash  and a half times higher than in . Almost half of these were people aged below .Veganism has brought with it a lucrative trade in plant-based produce as businesses move to accommodate the concerns of their customers and promote ethical alternatives to meat.Long before veganism became a dietary and commercial trendsetter, however, June Holder, a -year-old woman from Penarth, had her eyes opened to the costly effects of meat consumption. After eating a vegan breakfast at a local cafeacute, she settled down to tell me her story.ldquoIrsquove been vegan for  years, she said. ldquoMy daughter had a stall at Camden Market, and she used to collect masses of money for animal rights there. It was her who first introduced me to the cause.ldquoLater on, I organized a charity coffee morning and sent the money I raised to Compassion in World Farming. In , they sent me a magazine which showed what happened to the animals. Well, I sat down that morning and read what theyrsquod sent me ndash and I was vegan!Whilst the public has become more receptive to veganism, June still encounters hostility: ldquoPeoplersquos reactions y when I tell them Irsquom vegan. They become hostile because theyrsquore guilty, I suppose.ldquoI remember that a vegan group had a stall in the market a few years ago. They were advertising parts of Alsatians to eat. People were horried. So, when they were angry, I had a chance to talk to them. lsquoYou accept that any animal can be treated like this except when it comes to your dogsrsquo, I told them. Well, they had to accept it. How could they not Originally from Penarth, June moved to Dinas Powys from Barry after her husband, Derrick, passed away  years ago.Derrick was the owner of Holders Menswear, a menrsquos fashion store which was once renowned throughout the Vale of Glamorgan and beyond.Junersquos decision to become vegan sparked  years of dedication to activism. She joined the Animal Welfare Party, and, in her sixties and seventies, she travelled across the UK and Europe to campaign for animal rights.ldquoI demonstrated in many places. I went to Brussels twice to protest against the exportation of live animals. The International Fund for Animal Welfare took us in a coach.ldquoI was in the front row of the crowd, up against these spikes and razor wire. If they had started to push from the back, I dread to think what would have happened.ldquoThe night before the protest I had this thought: lsquoThe danger is not to protestrsquo. I wrote it on a little board.ldquoPeople kept tapping me on the shoulder and passing the board around the crowd and eventually it made its way back to me.What does the message mean ldquoIt means that it is more dangerous not to protest against these injustices that are happening.June still has a copy of the placard. Later, at her home, she retrieved it from a trove of scattered paraphernalia accumulated after years of protest.She has written prolically throughout her le about events which have provoked and enthused her. One poem describes the day of protest in Brussels. It reflects Junersquos unceasing dedication to animal welfare but also her frustration at the pace of change:ldquoThe writer of these verses was, quite some time ago, in Brussels with a poster which now rings yet more true. lsquoThe danger is not to protestrsquo is what the message said.ldquoThen round it went to young and old for everyone to read. From countries all round Europe, but the farmers paid no heed. Live transport, a huge issue then, continues just the same.Another poem read:ldquoChristmas is a time to spend, but why not save instead  In sheds around the country to sate the publicrsquos lust for something huge to set their feast. The turkeys just exist.ldquoTen million in this country at Christmas time alone. Is this the way to talk of peace and teach our children love Veganuary runs throughout January. The deadline to enter the ballot is on Monday January .Mr Starmer has previously criticised Labourrsquos non-committal approach to Brexit and said that it did not do enough to tackle anti-Semitism.He has also cautioned against calls to move away from Labourrsquos radical agenda and has committed to supporting Jeremy Corbyrsquos green new deal, outlined in the partyrsquos manesto, which proposes plans for a carbon neutral society.Labour members who join the party before pm on Monday,January , will be eligible to vote.In addition, supporters who register between Tuesday January  and Thursday January  and pay a pound fee will be able to take part in this ballot.Voting will begin on Friday February  and end on Thursday April .The candidates who have declared so far are:Sir Keir Starmer, shadow Brexit secretary,  nominationsRebecca Long Bailey, shadow business secretary,  nominationsLisa Nandy,  nominationsJess Phillips,  nominationsEmily Thornberry, shadow foreign secretary, nine nominationsClive Lewis, shadow minister for sustainable economics, four nominations article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Penarth by rolling a giantrsquos head down a hill.Hen Galen, the Old Welsh New Year, was celebrated last Sunday as hundreds of locals gathered at Penarth Clftops for the annual Penrolio .The welsh custom follows the tradition of the Julian calendar and involves the rolling of a giantrsquos head down a hill.Bran the Blessed, or Bendigeidfran in Welsh, is a giant from Welsh mythology.The celebrations began at .pm when the artist Ifor Davies read the story of the giant from the Mabinogion tales.The two-meter tall head, which was made by the artist, Haf Weighton, and pupils at Ysgol Penygarth, was then rolled towards the beach from Penarth Clftops.It was accompanied by singing and music from a wind and brass band.The Penarth, Monmouth and Brecon Mari Lwyd also attended the celebration.Mari Lwyd is an old Welsh custom in which a party carrying a horse skull on a pole sing and search for hospitality at peoplersquos doors.Whilst the giantrsquos head was carried along Penarth Beach, the Mari Lwyd party visited restaurants along the sea front to perform a traditional song.The festivities ended at the Penarth Pier Pavilion where the crowd performed a Mari Lwyd ceremony, followed by singing and refreshments.Richard Parry, a resident who attended the event, said:ldquoIt was lovely to see so many people, including families, turn out in the January weather to take part in this head rolling and celebration of the Old Welsh new year.ldquoThank you to everybody who took part, rolled, sang and visited the establishments along the seafront to wish them a happy new year.ldquoThe old Mabinogion stories are set along the Bristol Channel and its great that Penarth is celebrating the story of Bendigeidfran.ldquoThe story is a national treasure, and were delighted to be part of it."John Exton, who constructed the Penarth Mari Lwyd decoration with his we, Sue, said: ldquoThe Penarth Mari was an integral part of the procession. The event was well attended, and we estimate over two hundred turned up.ldquoAt present we have organised an exhibition in Chepstow Museum celebrating the tradition, with over  artists displaying work. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vaughan gething
story: As well as positives, there were of course negatives which should not be forgotten, but be built upon.The last decade saw me elected andto the National Assembly for Wales, appointed as Deputy Minister and then Minister for Health and Social Services.We also celebrated the birth of our son Isaac. I started the week as usual by walking Isaac to school, enjoying a father-son chat about the day ahead. has seen a rocky start with wildfires ravaging through Australia and tensions rising in the Middle East but this cannot set the tone for what is to come.As someone who has family in Australia, I am truly appalled to see the spread and devastation of the fires, but also the initial response from senior Australian politicians.Their denial of the link between the climate emergency which we face globally and the disaster which has swept across their nation is completely incomprehensible.Moving forward we must accept that we are in a state of emergency and must take drastic action to limit as much of the impact as practicably possible.We certainly have an interesting year,not decade ahead. The UKrsquos withdrawal from the EU will begin later this month and we have a Conservative Government in Westminster until at least .Regardless of the numbers in the Commons, the Labour Party still has to stand up for those we represent. I am confident that my colleague, Stephen Doughty MP will continue to do that.The Labour Party will now move to elect a new Leader and Deputy Leader, a chance to reunite the Party and hold the Prime Minister to account for his actions.I am truly glad to see that several MPs from across the Party have put their names forward to stand for both positions. This offers the membership and the country a broader choice.I am yet to decide who I will back in the forthcoming election but I know that I want to see a vision from each of the candidates. For me, that vision needs to be a realistic reflection of our last decade out of government in Westminster, but also a strategy for reconnecting with our voters and securing a Labour government which can deliver for those who need us most.Finally, I want to thank the staff across the NHS and wider public services for their hard work under increasing pressures, particularly during the winter period.Our public services work hard all year round and many take the sacrice of working over the Christmas and New Year period for which I, and many others, are extremely grateful.As everyou would like to speak with me, you can call my office on    or write to me at Vaughan.Gething@assembly.wales or Office of Vaughan Gething AM, Room C, National Assembly for Wales, CF NA. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Matt Pritchard, aka the Dirty Vegan" TV stuntman, Matt Pritchard, talks Dirty Vegan at Penarth Pier eventMatt Pritchard enages the crowd " TV stuntman, Matt Pritchard, talks Dirty Vegan at Penarth Pier eventMatt prepares a vegan meal from his new book" TV stuntman, Matt Pritchard, talks Dirty Vegan at Penarth Pier eventMatt in conversation with Mel Grfin of Grfin Books" TV stuntman, Matt Pritchard, talks Dirty Vegan at Penarth Pier eventMatt signs an audience memeber#s book" TV stuntman, Matt Pritchard, talks Dirty Vegan at Penarth Pier eventMatt Pritchard " Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTELEVISION stunt man, Matt Pritchard, ed to the Penarth Pier Pavilion last week to discuss his second vegan cookbook.Matt Pritchard began his television career by hurting himself and his friends for fun on the MTV stunt show, Dirty Sanchez.Almost  years later, Pritchard is still testing the bounds of taste. His second vegan recipe book, Dirty Vegan: Another Bite, was released last month alongside a tie-in BBC cookery programme.Last Friday, Matt Pritchard visited the Penarth Pier Pavilion to discuss his latest culinary enterprise and prepare a vegan dish with Mel Grfin of Grfin Books.Pritchard has not lost his mad-dash style and performative vigour. He relished his new role as he prepared for the talk: ldquoI enjoy it, man. Itrsquos better than shoving a drumstick up your arse on stage, he said.Originally from Cardf, Pritchard studied cooking at college but dedicated himself to professional skating when he was sponsored at .ldquoDirty Sanchez was great. It was just  years of mayhem.ldquoWe were getting paid to travel around the world. Getting drunk and off your head with your mates ndash thatrsquos like winning the lottery when yoursquore that age.ldquoI loved it. But then it took its toll on my mental health. Especially the drugs part of it.ldquoI needed to do something about it and thatrsquos when I started my fitness journey.ldquoWith my addictive personality, when I do something, Irsquove got to do it ndash not just dip my toes in.ldquoI started looking into veganism because a lot of endurance athletes were vegan. The more I researched it the more it started making sense to me.ldquoI love animals. Irsquove got a dog and I wouldnrsquot eat him. Whatrsquos the dference between a dog and a pig  All these things started making sense to me.ldquoAs soon as I became vegan, I felt healthier. So many people were trying to put me off it.ldquoBut on a vegan diet, I did The Decker, which is  full Iron Men in  days.ldquoNow Irsquom looking at doing the Double Decker which is  in  days. On my th birthday Irsquoll be doing  of something for  years.ldquoItrsquos another way of proving to people that veganism helps me, and that age is but a number.Pritchard became vegan in  and began to film his own cooking show on YouTube. In , the BBC aired the first series of Dirty Vegan.ldquoIf yoursquod told me  years ago that Irsquod be sitting here with you now and talking about vegan cooking books, I would I have laughed in your face, he said.Pritchard said that he was forced to leave Twitter last year because of abuse from online trolls and members of the Welsh farming community.Why were people so hostile ldquoBecause of guilt. Anger does it. Cognitive dissonance. Theyrsquore too lazy to change or they donrsquot want to believe it.ldquoBut the evidence is there. What I care about is the evidence and the animals."I donrsquot want to kill something that doesnrsquot want to be killed. If you eat steak, how can you say you care for all animals In his characteristic salt-of-the earth way, Pritchard hopes to entertain audiences with his new series whilst gently educating them about the benefits of vegan cooking.ldquoYou know, therersquos   arguing about Brexit. Therersquos   arguing about meat and veganism.ldquoWersquore all arguing amongst ourselves like lunatics. This show is just there for people to enjoy. ldquoTherersquos a bit of fun in it. Therersquos a lot of education.ldquoWhen it goes out on TV, I get a lot of positive messages from people saying theyrsquove cut down on meat. So, clearly, itrsquos doing something. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale council clamps flyposting
story: The local authority said it was an offence to affix a picture, letter or sign to any surface of a highway or to attach such an item to a tree, lamppost or any other aspect of the highway without express permission.Such a practice, it said, is a form of littering and can blight certain areas of the county, which is why the council says it plans to clamp down on it.Under Section  of the highways Act, the council has the authority to issue a pound fixed penalty notice per poster.In December last year, environmental enforcement officers noted  examples of flyposting, with every case at risk of this punishment.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoFlyposting is an unsightly and unwelcome practice that can have a signicant detrimental effect on the appearance of an area.ldquoThose responsible for flyposting should be warned that we will soon be exercising the extent of our powers to combat the issue.ldquoWe intend to come down hard on those responsible and anyone found to have committed this offence could be looking at a penalty of pound per poster. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Pupils consult the map" Pupils develop new walking mapPupils consult the map" Pupils develop new walking mapPupils consult the map" Pupils develop new walking mapPupils consult the map" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentPUPILS from Albert Primary School, Penarth, have developed new travel maps with the walking and cycling charity, Sustrans, and the Vale of Glamorgan CouncilOn Monday, January , Year  pupils from Albert Primary took part in a project to identy good quality walking and cycling areas in Penarth.The final aim of the project is to create an Active Travel Map using feedback gathered by the children.The map will be developed by the children to encourage higher levels of active travel to school.During the workshop, the children reviewed existing maps of Penarth to make them more intuitive. The pupils were then asked to redesign the maps by using their knowledge of the local area. They identied key landmarks, short cuts and potential barriers to walking and cycling.The pupils also developed a set of symbols and a map key which will be used in the new map.Sustrans also held a parent engagement workshop where they invited families to identy routes that they and their children use.Sustrans will produce a bilingual pocket-sized travel map which will be available to students, staff and parents for free. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentHMS Cambria Welsh Royal Naval Reservists marched through Barry town centre to bid farewell to the Vale on Saturday, January .The parade was a symbol of gratitude to Barry and the Vale for their valuable support and friendship spanning more than  years and came prior to their move to Cardf Bay in May .More than  members of Walesrsquos only Maritime Reserve Unit, together with a Ceremonial Guard, marched from King Square to the Civic Offices, led by the Band of Her Majestyrsquos Royal Marines Commando Training Centre.The Farewell Parade was attended by Lord Lieutenant of South Glamorgan, Morfudd Meredith, Vale mayor, Cllr Christine Cave Barry mayor, Cllr Margaret Wilkinson as well as High Sherrf, Dr Isabel Graham.Other attendees included, Captain David Teasdale RNR ndash deputy commander Maritime Reserves ndash and other civic dignitaries from across the region and past HMS Cambria commanding officers.HMS Cambria was awarded the Freedom of the County of the Vale of Glamorgan in April .HMS Cambria commander Steve Fry said: ldquoMy sailors are extremely honoured to march and show their gratitude to the Vale of Glamorgan.ldquoThis year will see us move into a multi-million pound building in the heart of Cardf Docks.ldquoOur relationship with the Vale and the town of Barry has been excellent and strengthened over nearly forty years of being located here.ldquoWe very much intend to maintain these strong links.Vale council cabinet member and armed forces champion, Cllr Eddie Williams said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome Royal Naval Reservists from HMS Cambria and other members of the military to Barry for this farewell parade and wish the unit well on relocation to their new site.ldquoAwarding the Freedom of the County Borough is a symbol of our trust and confidence in HMS Cambria and we are honoured by this show of appreciation.Deputy commander Maritime Reserves, Captain David Teasdale RNR, the senior Royal Navy officer attending, said: ldquoIt is very important that we remember and acknowledge the strong links built up with Barry and all the support the local community has given the shiprsquos company over many years.On behalf of the headquarters and Commander Maritime Reserves, I am extremely grateful for title: chance save life woman missed
story: Dr Deborah Lamont, , had been interrupted by police during an earlier suicide attempt in the room hours before her death, but an officer decided he was powerless to detain her as he deemed she was ldquoliving there.On Friday, a coroner said that although Dr Lamontrsquos death could not have been prevented as she was assessed as not being at immediate risk, it was a concern that officers may be wrongly interpreting sectioning powers.Coroner Graeme Hughes issued a report asking police to consider whether hotel rooms should be classed as homes for occupants, where people are unable to be sectioned, and called PC Barry Simpsonrsquos interpretation of the Mental Health Act ldquoprobably erroneous.He told the inquest in Pontypridd: ldquoPC Simpsonrsquos interpretation and application of Section , that he didnrsquot have power to detain Deborah because she was not in a public place, was probably erroneous.ldquoIn my judgment, it could not be said that in booking into a hotel room for one night that she was living in that room."He added: ldquoThe interpretation by PC Simpson is a concern and itrsquos a continuing concern because his evidence yesterday is he would still interpret Section  in the same way.The coroner said the officerrsquos judgment that Dr Lamont was not in need of immediate care or control was ldquoreasonable after he took advice from a mental health practitioner and she agreed to engage with mental health services the next day.The coroner gave a conclusion of suicide, and said he would send a report to the College of Policing to consider their future interpretation of a hotel room as a home.The court heard that Dr Lamont, from Dinas Powys, Vale of Glamorgan, struggled with depression and anxiety for decades, which worsened after orcing her husband of five years in .The university lecturer was awarded the Henry Dunant Medal, the highest honour the Red Cross gives members, after joining the emergency response team during the Grenfell Tower fire in .Red Cross colleague Jim Rees told South Wales Central Coronerrsquos Court he had received a series of worrying text messages from her on the afternoon before her death on March , .He called , which led to two police officers gaining access to Dr Lamontrsquos room at the Village Hotel in Cardf at around .pm.They saw evidence of an unsuccessful hanging attempt, and were later joined by paramedics and Mr Rees, before Dr Lamont was left alone in the room at around pm after it was agreed she was not in immediate need of care or control.Just before pm that evening, Pc Mitch Hughes and another officer were sent to the hotel after staff, who had been asked to check on Dr Lamont, became concerned for her when she failed to answer her door.The officers forced their way into the room and she was later declared dead.Dr Lamontrsquos father, Roger, told reporters: ldquoShe should have been sectioned. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url year.Cabinet members will consider the proposals, on Monday, February , before a meeting of all councillors on Wednesday, February .A larger than anticipated settlement from Welsh Government has increased the amount of investment that is possible and also eased the pressure on vital services.The financial settlement means the council will not need to increase council tax at a higher rate than last year.The Authority is proposing an increase of . per cent, which is below the projected Welsh average.The increase of . per cent was the preferred option when this matter was recently put to residents, with three times the average number of respondents making their views known in this yearrsquos budget consultation process.Tough decisions still need to be taken in the future as the council continues to deal with the fallout from  years of austerity.Under the budget proposals, schools will receive an extra pound million in the coming year, with poundmillion identied in the next two years to build new schools and renovate existing ones.pound. million will be spend on road resurfacing to improve the Valersquos highway network.pound, is to be invested into the area of neighbourhood services and transport.pound, will be pledged to school transport ndash avoiding the need to scale back current provision.pound. million will be put towards future projects aimed at tackling climate change.And nearly pound, is earmarked for electric vehicles to be added to the councilrsquos pool car fleet.Vale council leader, Cllr Neil Moore said: ldquoWe have listened to residents when it comes to our budget proposals for the next financial year.ldquoThe majority of those who responded to our consultation indicated they would prefer an increase in council tax of . per cent alongside some cuts that would normally accompany such a modest rise.ldquoThat is exactly what we are proposing, but without the need to cut services.ldquoOur suggested budget includes plans for signicant investment in schools, which will mean better facilities and improved learning environments for our children, as well as money to be spent on infrastructure throughout the county.ldquoIt is important to stress that even though this promising news about our Welsh Government funding is welcome, it does not represent a magic wand and solve our financial situation.ldquoWe will still have some dficult issues to address brought about by the decade-long underfunding of councils across Wales.ldquoWe will attempt to be creative in meeting this challenge, aiming to improve efficiency by title: this weeks letters
story: Some delegates at an annual teachersrsquo conference have reportedly drawn attention to evidence of poverty among the schoolchildren they teach.The evidence relates to occasional lack of decent breakfasts before their coming to school in the mornings.I am inclined to think that that case is well made, as has been recognised by the occasional provision of food at the schools. It is surely shocking that that should be necessary, however.Where I might wish to deviate from the teachersrsquo critique is a reference to school unorms being worn out of school hours, perhaps at weekends or during school holidays.So what There were no unorms at my primary school, in Penarth, but at my secondaryschool, in Cardf, there were. Some of us would wear our school unorms out of school hours, and did not at all see this as a badge of poverty. But the problem of lack of food, where it is identied, is a serious one.As an undergraduate in the s, most of us wore blazers, badges, ties and college scarves, and they would often be worn outside teaching hours, unlike our academic gowns, worn for lectures, especially in the low faculty .Michael, OrsquoNeillRailway TerracePenarthSociety in rude healthAn article in a recent edition of the Penarth Timessomehow managed to give a completely  impression that the Penarth Civic Society was in dficulties and was lsquofighting to preserve its existencersquo.In fact, the reverse is true.The society is going from strength to strength and the request by our committee member, Anne Evans, for people with secretarial and or legal skills to join us is to support the expanding range of activities the society is engaged in.We always welcome applications from new members, whether to assist with the work of the committee or to just support the work we do and enjoy the other benefits of membership.But the society is not, as the article suggested, fighting to avoid an early demise and we remain in the best of health.Chris WyattHonorary TreasurerPenarth Civic SocietyHeroes of the skyPeople have heard of Barnes WallisAnd Guy Gibson, who traversed the streets of Penarth,But this poem is a tribute to Gordon YeoWho grew up in old Barry town.He flew with the famous Dambusters,Shot down when only twenty,Such a tragedy that he was killedWith so many of his dreams unfulfilledIn Lancasters they must have felt like gods,Mortal gods with flimsy flesh.Three dams were attacked with bouncing ballsAnd the Moehne and Eder were breached,Water gushing into the valley belowBut claiming civilians and forced labourers tooFor war is brutal causing fear and pain,Eight bombers never came home again.I picture empty seats the next dayAnd surviving airmen eating breakfastWith sad thoughts about fallen comrades.There is a portrait of the Welsh Dambuster,I canrsquot imagine the terror he feltAs deadly flak raced towards his planeSo herersquos to you, hero of the sky,A man of courage, far too young to die.Guy FletcherDan-y-GraigPantmawrCardfCuts to youth servicesJust when you thought title: labours membership surges election defeat report blames brexit
story: The post-mortem examination circulated to the partyrsquos ruling National Executive Committeefound it would be ldquounrealistic not to say its policy to hold a fresh referendum played a ldquodecisive role.Radicalism was largely ruled out as being at fault in the report by election co-ordinators Andrew Gwynne and Ian Lavery, but they did blame a glut of policies for confusing the public.While the MPs accepted there were ldquonegative views of the outgoing leader, there was little blame laid at any of his actions.The increase in membership to what was described as the partyrsquos largest number ever was revealed at an NEC meeting on Tuesday. Last summer the membership stood at ,.A senior Labour source said: ldquoThe Labour Party was already by far the biggest party in Britain. It is now even bigger ndash as big as it has ever been.The members will vote along with other supporters for Mr Corbynrsquos successor, who will be tasked with restoring the party from its gravest general election defeat since .The swelling in support after the loss could signal a blow for shadow business secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey, who is closely aligned with the current leadership.Labour entered the election with a stance of holding another EU referendum on the options of Remain and a ldquocredible departure deal.The official report contrasted this policy with the ldquoendlessly-repeated clarity of the Toriesrsquo ldquomisleading promise to lsquoget Brexit donersquo.The ldquoprolonged uncertainty of Labourrsquos position took its toll on support as did its failures in advancing positive proposals for resolving Brexit in Parliament, the report said.This allowed Labour to be ldquounfairly painted as part of an ldquoobstructive establishment thwarting the peoplersquos will, it continued.Key seat targeting in the campaign was also blamed in the report, which shielded the role of the partyrsquos radical manesto saying its  pledges secured a massive vote increase despite being attacked with ldquocomparable venom.ldquoIt is unlikely that radicalism was in itself the problem in a country looking for change, the document said, but pointed towards the scale of pledges seeming ldquoimplausible to many voters.The report concluded that ldquotoo many policieshellip were launched on an almost daily basis which ldquoconfused the public as to our sense of priorities and disorientated activists.It accepted there were growing ldquonegative views of the leader which were ldquostrongly affected by the Brexit crisis.ldquoThere is also little doubt that four years of unrelenting attacks on the character of the party leader, an assault without precedent in modern politics, had a degree of negative impact, the report said.The report was interpreted by some as having absolved Mr Corbyn, a position that was rejected by leadership hopeful Lisa Nandy.ldquoI havenrsquot seen the report but I think none of us can be exonerated for the worst election defeat since , the Wigan MP told LBC.She said the Brexit position was a factor, which she accused the leadership of having hit the ldquosweet spot where both sides of the ide thought the party was against them.She also said she was now in a ldquolovely place having taken Twitter off her phone in an attempt to connect with the voters and not the ldquoWestminster bubble.The focus on the social media ldquohothouse has been a major problem for the left, Ms Nandy argued, leading to misguided beliefs over when it is failing or succeeding.ldquoWe should be out there amongst the publicwe really want to understand whatrsquos happening, she said.Ms Nandy and Sir Keir Starmer have both succeeded in getting onto the final ballot of members and supporters to pick the new leader, who will be announced on April .The remaining contenders, Ms Long-Bailey and Emily Thornberry, are still trying to attract sufficient support from unions and affiliated organisations, but the former seems guaranteed to leap story: The aircraft manufacturer said on Wednesday that it lost one billion dollarsin the fourth quarter as revenue plunged % due to the grounding of the Max, which stopped new deliveries of the plane.The icon of US manufacturing lost  million dollarsfor all of .The company took a pre-tax charge of . billion dollarsto cover more concessions to airlines that have cancelled thousands of flights without their Max jets.Including higher estimated production costs in the years ahead, Boeing recalculated its extra expenses for the Max at . billion dollars .The Max was grounded last March after two crashes five months apart killed  people in Indonesia and Ethiopia.The crisis has left Boeing far behind rival Airbus in sales and deliveries of new jetliners, caused lay-offs at suppliers and led to the firing of CEO Dennis Muilenburg.Boeing executives are scheduled to discuss the fourth-quarter results with analysts later on Wednesday.It will be the first earnings call for new CEO David Calhoun, a former General Electric and Nin executive who has been on Boeingrsquos board since ..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Boeing posts first annual loss since  article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: lloyds halifax bank scotland branches close
story: The banking giant has confirmed plans to shut  Lloyds,  Halax and  Bank of Scotland branches between April and October .The company said the closures are part of a store reduction programme in response to changing customer behaviour and the move towards online banking.A Lloyds Banking Group spokeswoman said: ldquoWe are committed to having the largest branch network in the UK and, in addition to our branches, all our customers can also use the Post Office to access their banking locally, alongside our mobile branches which visit many rural communities.ldquoWe have confirmed that a number of branches will close between April and October this year.ldquoThis is in response to changing customer behaviours and the reduced number of transactions being made in branches.It comes as the bank continues its closure programme which affected Lloyds and Halax sites in . --Lloyds Banking Group to close another  branches .Accords comment is here: https:t.co BqlRVymdash Accord UnionJanuary , In a statement, Accord said: ldquoWe fully appreciate that the demand for high street branch banking is diminishing as customers increasingly move to app-based banking but wersquoll be examining Lloyds Banking Grouprsquos plans to ensure that theyrsquore properly thought through and robustly evidenced.ldquoSo far, all branch closures have been managed without compulsory redundancies and Accord expects the same outcome here.ldquoWersquoll be contacting our members who are impacted by the closures to offer support and representation..push,i[r].l*new supplement everyday living costsBy Group ReporterTuesday, th January , : pm""Parents are dipping into their kids savings to supplement day-to-day living costs, a study has found.Researchers polled , mums and dads and found one fth have borrowed money from their childrens piggy banks and accounts in order to pay their living expenses.Nearly half of those have taken cash out of their little ones savings to pay household bills, with  per cent borrowing money to cover the cost of groceries.And, ironically, more than one sixth have done so in order to cover childcare.The research was commissioned by comparethemarket as part of their latest Parentdex report on pocket moneyJody Coughlan, Money Manager, at comparethemarket said: "Fortunately for kids, the wider squeeze on the household budget seems to have had little impact on the generous amounts parents wants to give their children."That said, parents do need to ensure that they are able to give their kids this pocket money, without needing to dip into it to cover wider household bills."The report uncovers the spending habits of British children who receive an average of £ a month, totalling £ every year and giving them the equivalent of £.billion to spend collectively.Research also found kids savings accounts are relatively healthy, with the average child having a signicant £. stashed away.In fact, one fth of children have £, sitting in their savings.It also emerged children are generating a second source of income, with four in five parents giving their offspring extra money to cover unforeseen requests such as new clothing or nights out with friends.These ad hoc requests see one fth of parents topping up pocket money once a fortnight, and more than a quarter giving these extra handouts once a month.Meanwhile, the Bank of Gran and Grandad appears to be another fruitful source of income for kids.One quarter of grandparents find themselves contributing to kids income, with two thirds giving their grandkids generous handouts as and when they see them.Unsurprisingly, children in the capital are the recipients of the highest amount of pocket money compared to anywhere  in the UK, with the average parent in London giving £ to their child each month.In contrast, children in the east of England are given £ a month while those in the south west who are given £.Fortunately, the poll also shows mums and dads are confident in their childrens ability to manage their finances effectively, with almost three quarters believing the youngsters will be well equipped to handle money as they approach adulthood.In the absence of financial education at schools, this could be down to discussions at home, with nine in  stating they have talked about money management with their children.However, parents clearly feel their children would benefit from additional teaching in schools, with four fths of those polled believing schools should do more to teach financial education.Jody Coughlan added: "Its incredibly encouraging to see the number of parents who are willing to talk to their children about financial management from such an early age."Not only will this do more to prepare them for financial responsibility in the long run, but it should also help to lessen their long-term dependence on the Bank of Mum and Dad as a result!"""Most Popular." data-index"" retailers brace for ‘tough year’Retail sales fell flat in January as high street retailers suffered a bruising start to , according to new figures.By The NewsroomTuesday, th January , : pm""Janaury has proved a dficult month for retailersThe CBI’s monthly distributive trends survey showed that retailers saw sales volumes flatline for the third month in a row.It said Britain’s high street will brace itself for “another tough year for the sector”, as it predicted sales would remain flat through February.Sales were “poor for the time of year”, the CBI said, predicting they will remain below seasonal norms for the year to February.Anna Leach, deputy chief economist at the CBI, said: “Both official data and business surveys are painting a picture of subdued activity for retailers.“A challenging Christmas has extended into the New Year, with little expectation of any improvement soon.”Department store sales were particularly good during the month, but were offset by weaker performances by DIY retailers and furniture shops.The survey data also revealed that orders placed with suppliers fell as retailers maintained high levels of stock.Stagnating retail sales will add to the uncertainties of the wider economy, ahead of Mark Carney’s final monetary policy committee as governor of the Bank of England on Thursday.The CBI also called on the Chancellor to stimulate the retail sector by overhauling the current business rates system.Howard Archer, chief economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, said: “It is still early days to see what impact December’s decisive general election result and imminent UK exit from the EU on  January with a deal has on consumer behaviour.“The initial signs are that it has lted confidence but this - so far at least - has not translated
